definition[0]: behaving or speaking in a way that is correct for the social situation you are in, and showing that you are careful to consider other people’s needs and feelings
example[3]: We left the party as soon as it was polite to do so.
note[0]: it is polite (of somebody) to do something
example[4]: It’s not polite to talk with your mouth full.
definition[1]: you make polite conversation, remarks etc because it is considered socially correct to do this, but not necessarily because you believe what you are saying
example[5]: I know Ian said he liked her singing, but he was only being polite.
example[6]: While they ate, they made polite conversation about the weather.
example[7]: Jan expressed polite interest in Edward’s stamp collection.
example[8]: He was too polite to ask how old she was.
example[9]: ‘Excuse me, sir, ’ she said in a polite voice.
definition[2]: having good manners and knowing the correct way to behave in social situations
example[10]: She was beautifully dressed and very well-mannered.
definition[3]: polite and not causing any trouble – used about children or animals
example[12]: Well-behaved dogs are welcome at the hotel.
definition[4]: polite and respectful, and behaving rather formally
example[13]: The hotel staff were very courteous and helpful.
definition[5]: polite and treating someone with respect
example[15]: He was very respectful towards all my relatives.
example[16]: ‘Thank you, ’ he said with a respectful bow.
definition[6]: polite in a formal way, especially when you do not feel very friendly towards someone
example[17]: She’d never liked her father-in-law, but she forced herself to be civil to him.
example[18]: When you’ve stopped arguing, you might be able to have a civil conversation.
definition[7]: polite towards someone, especially because they are in a more important social position
example[19]: In those days women were expected to be deferential to men.
